content.body:
There are vague future plans for object-literal decorators like `@(d) { x: 0 }`. So:
```js
x |> @(d)
{ x: 0 }
```
â€¦also needs to be future proofed with an early error. We presumably should do the same with array literals. (And tuple/record literals when they come.)

Blocks are fine.
```js
x |> @(d)
{ 0 }
```
â€¦only has one reasonable interpretation (as `x |> @(d); { 0 }`).

I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anything else on the expression level that might get decoratedâ€¦Maybe identifiers? Right now there are only plans for parameter identifiers so maybe we also ban this too:

```js
x |> @(d)
y
```

content.body: So the plan is to use a cover grammar ShortCircuitExpression `|>` CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression. PipeBody is the usual. DecoratedExpression is something like DecoratorList Expression. Itâ€™s an early error if DecoratedExpression covers CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression.
content.formatted_body: So the plan is to use a cover grammar ShortCircuitExpression |> CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression. PipeBody is the usual. DecoratedExpression is something like DecoratorList Expression. Itâ€™s an early error if DecoratedExpression covers CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression.

content.body: I have heard about obejct property decorators, but never about decorators for the whole object. It can just be a function call?
Not sure. Take a look at https://github.com/tc39/proposal-decorators/blob/master/EXTENSIONS.md#object-literal-and-property-decorators-and-annotations.
It feels a bit that pipeline is taking into account other possible proposals in a way that many other proposals don't.

content.body: Since (if?) weâ€™re going with `@` as the topic reference, I think itâ€™s reasonable to try to future proof against any potential future conflict with future decorator extensions.
content.formatted_body: Since (if?) weâ€™re going with @ as the topic reference, I think itâ€™s reasonable to try to future proof against any potential future conflict with future decorator extensions.

content.body: Itâ€™s only decorators really that pipe has to be careful about.
* The only proposal that that pipe has to be careful about is decorators.

m.new_content.body: The only proposal that that pipe has to be careful about is decorators.

content.body: It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.

content.body: (â€¦Well, I guess thereâ€™s the dataflow stuff in general. Like how pipe will not advance unless bind-this advances. But Iâ€™m talking about syntax only.)

> <@pokute:matrix.org> It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.

I donâ€™t think we have to be careful about future non-identifier infix operators. Itâ€™s future infix operators that have to be careful of pipe (or specifically of the `@` topic). And those future proposals will be able to use some simple lookahead rules when they get proposed (https://github.com/tc39/proposal-pipeline-operator/issues/91#issuecomment-1085006912), and it should be fine.

content.body: I wish we could just ban ASI after pipes
If that would be enough
Iâ€™ll think about if we can do that instead.
But the problem isnâ€™t that ASI is happening. Itâ€™s that developers might expect ASI to happen when it wouldnâ€™t.
content.formatted_body: But the problem isnâ€™t that ASI is happening. Itâ€™s that developers might expect ASI to happen when it wouldnâ€™t.

content.body:
```js
x |> @(d)
class C {}
```
Here, ASI would *not* happen. It would be equivalent to:
```js
x |> (@(d) class C {})
```
But a developer might expect ASI to happen, as if it were:
```js
x |> @(d); class C {}
```
content.formatted_body:
x |> @(d)
class C {}

Here, ASI would not happen. It would be equivalent to:

x |> (@(d) class C {})

But a developer might expect ASI to happen, as if it were:

x |> @(d); class C {}

a = b

content.body: We could ask to the other delegates if anyone feels like all those decorators extensions are a possibility on the future

I think itâ€™s reasonable to just ban PipeExpression : ShortCircuitExpression `|>` DecoratorList Expression.
Come to think of it, we probably donâ€™t even need a cover grammar.
